did.head: DESCRIPTIVE SUMMARY
did.unittitle: Papers of the International Labor Defense on Microfilm, 1842-1951
did.repository: Kheel Center for Labor-Management Documentation and Archives, Cornell University Library
did.abstract: Part of 'Black Studies Research Sources', General Editors - August Meier and John H. Bracey, Jr.

bioghist.head: ORGANIZATIONAL HISTORY
bioghist.p: The International Labor Defense (ILD) was legal advocacy organization established in the United States as the American section of the Comintern's International Red Aid network. The ILD defended Sacco and Vanzetti, was active in the civil rights and anti-lynching movements, and prominently participated in the defense and legal appeals in the cause celebre of the Scottsboro Boys. In 1946 the ILD was merged with National Federation for Constitutional Liberties to form the Civil Rights Congress, which served as the new legal defense organization of the Communist Party USA. [Wikipedia]

scopecontent.p: Topics Included: Cases resulting from distributing literature and attempting to organize workers; cases resulting from holding meetings and demonstrations; deportation cases; cases resulting from picketing and general strike activity; cases resulting from the National Textile Workers' Union; sedition and criminal syndicalist cases; cases resulting from general capitalist terror campaign; additional cases growing from strike activity; Tom Mooney and Warren Billings cases; Centralia, Washington, cases; miscellaneous cases

did.unittitle: 0053. Box 1/Folder a3. Minutes and Reports.
0054. Box 1/Folder a3. Program for Round Table Discussions at the National Conference of the International Labor Defense to be Held in Washington, D.C. 4 pages.

scopecontent.p: June 19-21, 1937. Topics included: Criminal syndicalism and related repressive legislation; protection of the foreign-born and the right of asylum; the present situation in Puerto Rico; prison conditions in the United States and the recognition of the status of political prisoners; the events in Spain today and their significance to the American people; anti-lynching legislation and defense of the rights of the Negro people; the Tom Mooney case; civil rights in America today.

Ramsey-Frank J. Connor case; Sheppard-Hill bill; right of asylum; protection of foreign born; the Dies bill; Matthias Rakosi; embargo on arms to Italy and Germany; legislative program; adoption of constitution of International Labor Defense; Tampa, Florida, Joseph Shoemaker case; murder of Frank Norman; the Black Legion; Alabama; Arkansas.
